text.tspan: data reduction typically needs more than a single copy
=> 3x (if we try hard) to 10x (more realistic) more memory
a system with 2 CPUs and some RAM (main memory)
=> out of memory after 20 to 80 minutes
1. keeping historical events somewhere (events older than a few minutes)
2. re-processing historical events on demand (change reduction script, re-bin everything, ...)
3. keep only reduced data, e.g., I(Q,t) with certain time resolution
4. any fancy scheme we can think of for a specific reduction type
All of these limit options and flexibility -- but may be perfect for some cases
Buy more nodes for reduction cluster ($$$):
2. more compute power => can afford more re-processing of historical events
3. may be "limited" to 10s or 100s of nodes, depending on instrument, more may slow down processing

tspan.tspan: Load historical events from disk when needed ($$$, compromise):

text.tspan: 1. do not have more nodes for processing => limited computed power for re-processing
2. reading from disk is slow => potentially very high cost if we require IO-speed >> event-rate
3. IO speed will limit the number of use cases where is is useful
